did.abstract: The University of Kentucky. Associate Provost for Multicultural and Academic Affairs and Office of Minority Affairs: Lauretta Byars papers (dated 1948-2007, undated; bulk 1990-2005; 11 cubic feet, 11 record storage cartons) primarily comprise correspondence, reports and planning documents, financial records, meeting agendas and minutes, subject files and institutional data, event flyers, and printed material documenting the administration and operations of and events undertaken by the Office of Minority Affairs (1990-2003) and the Office of Multicultural and Academic Affairs (2003-2004) during Lauretta Byars' tenure as head administrator.

accessrestrict.head: Conditions Governing Access
accessrestrict.p: Collection is open to researchers by appointment

arrangement.head: Arrangement
arrangement.p: Collection is arranged by subject into three series: Administrative Files, Subject Files, and Lauretta Byars Personal Files.

bioghist.head: Historical and Biographical Note
bioghist.p: In 1971, the University of Kentucky Board (UK) of Trustees established the position of Assistant to the Vice President for Student Affairs for Minority Students and hired Jerry L. Stevens to fill it. The role of this position was to advise, assist, and counsel the University and its administration "in the interest of improving current efforts and developing new services for minority students." Simultaneously, the Office of Minority Student Affairs was created. The office reported to the Vice President for Student Affairs and the goal of the office was to "assist both students and University staff in the development of coordinated programs and supportive services for minority students when specific needs cannot be met effectively through the use of existing resources." In addition, the office provided institutional support and representation for underrepresented student, faculty, and staff populations at the university.

In July 1975, John T. Smith was hired for a newly-created position, the Vice President for Minority Affairs, which became Vice Chancellor for Minority Affairs June 1982 when the University instituted a chancellor system. This position was over the areas of Minority Student Affairs, Affirmative Action, and Employee Counseling. William C. Parker took over the position in August 1984, and Lauretta Byars was hired as acting Vice Chancellor in July 1990. After a national search, Byars was appointed permanently in April 1991.

In October 1991, the Lyman T. Johnson Alumni Association (affiliated with the UK Alumni Association) as part of the celebration of the 20th anniversary of the office. During this time, the office focused on developing educational and cultural programming, the recruitment and retention of minority students and non-academic counseling. In July 2001, the position of Vice Chancellor of Minority Affairs was renamed Associate Provost of Minority Affairs. Based on one of the recommendations of then-President Lee T. Todd to the Board of Trustees, the Office of Minority Affairs was renamed the Office of Multicultural and Academic Affairs effective July 1, 2003. Byars continued as head of the unit as the Associate Provost for Multicultural and Academic Affairs. The units and programs under this office expanded to include the UK Center for Academic Resources and Enrichment Services (UK CARES), the Freshman Summer Program, the Critical First-Year Program, the Science Living-Learning Community, the Martin Luther King, Jr., Cultural Center, Multicultural Student Programming, and Student Support Services. The name change reflected the broader range of services and broader mission acquired by the office, which was to "assume university-wide responsibility to lead diversity and equity efforts across the campus."

Just a year later, in July 2004, the Board of Trustees established a new administrative position reporting to the President and the Provost, the Vice President for University Initiatives/Associate Provost for Multicultural Affairs. Under this new position, the Board consolidated the areas of the Vice President for Academic Outreach and Public Service, the Vice President for Research and Economic Development, and the Associate Provost for Multicultural and Academic Affairs. The new position was "responsible for outreach and service programs on behalf of the communities throughout Kentucky, particularly in Appalachia, promoting the University's ability to develop and evaluate solutions to some of the state's most persistent social, economic, health, and educational problems, improving the recruitment and academic success of multicultural students, and providing oversight of the University's efforts to enhance its overall diversity." Also, in 2004, Lauretta Byars left the university, and William H. Turner was appointed to this new position. In September 2005, Philip A. Greasley was appointed as Associate Vice President for University Initiatives. In June 2006, the position name changed slightly to Vice President for University Engagement/Associate Provost for Multicultural and Academic Affairs.

In November 2006, the Board of Trustees established a Vice President for Institutional Diversity to serve as the "...senior administrative officer responsible for promoting collaboration across faculty, staff, administration, and students in earnest pursuit of the university's diversity goals." In 2008, Judy "JJ" Jackson was hired into this new position, the office was renamed the Office for Institutional Diversity, and the position of Associate Provost for Multicultural Affairs was eliminated. Currently, the office now manages several units including the Center for Academic Resources and Enrichment Services (CARES) department; Center for Graduate and Professional Diversity Initiatives department; Office of LGBTQ* Resources department; Martin Luther King Center; the Kentucky-West Virginia Louis Stokes Alliance for Minority Participation; Inclusive Excellence and Education; and Student Support Services. The departments are known to "work across academic and non-academic units to implement ideas, collaborate on outreach and recruitment efforts, and to enhance student retention and achievement." Following Judy Jackson's retirement in 2015, Sonja Feist-Price (2017-2020) and Gerald Wright (2020- ) have led the unit. The complete list of leaders includes Jerry L. Stevens (1971-1975). John T. Smith (1975-1984), William C. Parker (1984-1990), Lauretta Byars (1990-2004), William H. Turner (2004-2005), Philip A. Greasley (2005-2008), Judy "JJ" Jackson (2008-2015), Sonja Feist-Price (2017-2020), and Gerald C. Wright (2020- ).

Lauretta Flynn Byars was born on April 4th, 1949. She obtained her Bachelor of Arts degree from Morehead State University in 1970, her Masters in Social Work in 1972 from the University of Kentucky, and her Doctorate in Education in 1982 from the University of Kentucky. A member of the faculty of the UK College of Social Work, prior to her appointment at UK as Vice Chancellor of Minority Affairs in 1990, Byars served as Director of the Undergraduate Program (1985-1990), Assistant Dean for Student Affairs in the UK College of Social Work (1980-1985), and as Executive Director of the federal Office of Education grant-funded University Educational Talent Search (1972-1979). In 2001, her title changed to Associate Provost for Multicultural and Academic Affairs, heading the activities of that office. Her responsibilities included budgeting, personnel management, planning, recruiting and retaining students, supporting minority faculty and staff, and helping to ensure a positive and supportive environment for diversity at the University. She is noted for transforming the office from Minority Affairs to the Office Of Multicultural and Academic Affairs (2003), generating more than $4.5 million in external funding, and establishing the Jamal Mashburn Endowment Scholarship and critical first-year retention programs. Byars left UK in 2004 to become the Vice President for Institutional Relations and Public Service at Prairie View A&M University in Prairie View, Texas. In 2008, she was appointed Vice President for Student Affairs and Institutional Relations. She retired from Prairie View A&M in 2018.

Sources: 1. University of Kentucky Bulletin. General Information for Undergraduates, vol. 66, no. 5, 1974-1975. 2. University of Kentucky University Senate (Faculty Senate) meeting minutes, 1971 September 13 and 1990 November 12 3. Blackford, Linda. "Long Search for UK diversity chief results in one internal candidate." Lexington Herald-Leader, 2017 March 2. https://www.kentucky.com/article135961583.html 4. Office for Institutional Diversity. "Units and Contacts." https://www.uky.edu/inclusiveexcellence/units-contacts 5. University of Kentucky Board of Trustees. Meeting Minutes, 1972 June 14; 1975 Jan. 27; 1982 June 22; 1984 Sept. 18; 1990 June 19; 1991 Oct 22; 2003 September 16; 2004 May 4; 2004 June 2; 2005 September 20 8. 2020ua031 : "Minority Affairs Office, 1971-1992." University of Kentucky. Special Collections Research Center. Office of Minority Affairs/Office of Multicultural Affairs/Office for Institutional Diversity General Records. University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.

prefercite.head: Preferred Citation
prefercite.p: 2004ua064 : [identification of item], University of Kentucky. Office of Minority Affairs and Office of Multicultural and Academic Affairs: Lauretta Byars papers, 1948-2007, undated, bulk 1990-2005, University of Kentucky Libraries Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: The University of Kentucky. Associate Provost for Multicultural and Academic Affairs and Office of Minority Affairs: Lauretta Byars papers (dated 1948-2007, undated; bulk 1990-2005; 11 cubic feet, 11 record storage cartons) primarily comprise correspondence, reports and planning documents, financial records, meeting agendas and minutes, subject files and institutional data, event flyers, and printed material documenting the administration and operations of and events undertaken by the Office of Minority Affairs (1990-2003) and the Office of Multicultural and Academic Affairs (2003-2004) during Lauretta Byars' tenure as head administrator. The offices' administrative activities include semester planning meetings and workshops; oversight and tracking of annual budgets, income and expenses; and short-term and long-term goal setting and evaluation. Operating activities include leadership of and participation on university and Lexington, Ky., committees and boards; fundraising for and establishment and management of scholarships, endowments, and awards; and planning for and carrying out events and long-term programs. Subject files include statistical data, journal articles, news clippings, and university institutional data on a range of multicultural topics that informed the work of the Office of Minority Affairs and Office of Multicultural and Academic Affairs primarily during the 1990s and 2000s. There is also a small amount of Byar's personal papers,including resumes, articles and publisher correspondence, and research files documenting Lauretta Byars' professional and academic work.

userestrict.head: Conditions Governing Use
userestrict.p: Property rights reside with the University of Kentucky. The University of Kentucky holds the copyright for materials created in the course of business by University of Kentucky employees. Copyright for all other materials has not been assigned to the University of Kentucky. For information about permission to reproduce or publish, please contact the Special Collections Research Center.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Comprises correspondence and memoranda, reports and planning documents, budgets and other financial records, meeting agendas and minutes, event flyers, and printed material documenting the operations administration and events undertaken by the Office of Minority Affairs and the Office of Multicultural and Academic Affairs primarily from 1990 to 2005 during Lauretta Byars' tenure as head. The offices' administrative activities include semester planning meetings and workshops; oversight and tracking of annual budgets, income and expenses; and short-term and long-term goal setting and evaluation. Operating activities include leadership of and participation on university and Lexington, Ky., committees and boards such as the Equal Opportunity Panel and Inclusive Learning Community; fundraising for and establishment and management of scholarships, endowments, and awards; and planning for and carrying out events and long-term programs, including Advancement Via Individual Determination (AVID), the UK-Central High School (Louisville, Ky.) partnership, the Lyman T. Johnson Alumni organization and scholarships, the Martin Luther King, Jr., Celebration (Lexington, Ky.), First Year Focus initiative, Partnership for Reform Initiatives in Science and Mathematics (PRISM), Gear-Up program, and Freshman Summer Program. The series also includes records documenting the activities of units within the Office. The series is arranged into five subseries by format or subject and thereunder alphabetically by folder title: Annual Reports and Planning, Committees and Boards, Financial, General, and Programming. Original folder titles have been retained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Comprises statistical data, journal articles, news clippings, and university institutional data on a range of multicultural topics that informed the work of the Office of Minority Affairs and Office of Multicultural and Academic Affairs primarily during the 1990s and 2000s. Topics include national, Kentucky, and university diversity and inclusion activities, organizations, and conferences; African American, minority, and multicultural UK student admissions, recruitment and retention, demographics, scholarly success, and graduate rates; Kentucky-wide high school student demographics; multicultural events and figures in Lexington and across the state; economic disparity; minorities in higher education; race; and class. The series is arranged into three subseries by topic and thereunder alphabetically by folder title : University of Kentucky, Kentucky, and General. Original folder titles have been retained.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Comprises resumes, articles and publisher correspondence, and research files documenting Lauretta Byars' professional and academic work. Articles include "Lexington's Colored Orphan Industrial Home, 1892-1913"; "Rethinking Sisterhood: Dynamics of Race and Class in a Southern Community"; "Meeting the Need: Raising Funds for Higher Education"; and "Illusive Equality: Blacks in Higher Education in Kentucky 1866-1931". Research topics include the Colored Orphan Industrial Home, the Colored Women's Club, and the Colored League of Women Voters.
